did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Nature Conservancy in Arizona records (1884-1999) documents the activities of the Arizona Chapter of The Nature Conservancy, an international non-profit conservation organization dedicated to protecting rare plants and animals and the land and water they need to survive.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: It is the responsibility of the user to obtain permission to publish from the owner of the copyright (the institution, the creator of the record, the author or his/her transferees, heirs, legates, or literary executors). The user agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the Arizona Board of Regents for the University of Arizona, its officers, employees, and agents from and against all claims made by any person asserting that he or she is an owner of copyright.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Nature Conservancy in Arizona records (MS 408). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Nature Conservancy in Arizona is the Arizona Chapter of The Nature Conservancy, an international non-profit conservation organization dedicated to protecting rare plants and animals and the land and water they need to survive. Its mission is to find, protect, and maintain the best examples of rare species and biological communities in the natural world. The Arizona Chapter of The Nature Conservancy, established in 1966, is committed to protecting this natural diversity by partnering with public agencies and private landowners to create and manage a statewide system of natural preserves that protects valuable habitat for Arizona's vanishing wildlife. This system of managed preserves includes: Hassayampa River Preserve, Hartwell Canyon Preserve, Hart Prairie Preserve, Aravaipa Canyon Preserve, Muleshoe Ranch Cooperative Management Area, Ramsey Canyon Preserve, Canelo Hills Cienega Preserve and Patagonia-Sonoita Creek Preserve. To date, The Nature Conservancy in Arizona has helped to protect more than 1.5 million acres of ecologically important land in the state. The organization has been instrumental in affecting changes in state trust land policy and federal legislation for the conservation of special areas and water resources The Conservancy has also initiated bi-national cooperative conservation efforts with Mexico to protect key areas such as Los Fresnos Ranch in Sonora, Mexico, which is an important freshwater source for the San Pedro River in Arizona.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into 2 subgroups. Subgroup 1, The Nature Conservancy in Arizona, Chapter Materials, contains five series: Administration, Correspondence, Communications, Program, and Research and Reference files. Subgroup 2, Site Files, contains forty-two series arranged alphabetically by site name.

Subgroup 1: The Nature Conservancy in Arizona, Chapter Materials,
1962-1999
Series 6: Buenos Aires National Wildlife Refuge, 1982-1992
Series 25: Muleshoe Ranch Cooperative Management Area, 1884-1997
Series 38: Vekol Valley Special Management area, 1988

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Nature Conservancy in Arizona records (1884-1999) primarily documents the activities of the Arizona Chapter of The Nature Conservancy, an international non-profit conservation organization dedicated to the global preservation of natural diversity by identifying rare plants and animals and acquiring and protecting the land and water they need to survive. The materials in Subgroup 1 consist of the administration, correspondence, communications, program, and research and reference records of the organization. Subgroup 2 materials consist of site files for 42 sites, which may include one or more of the following subseries: administration, correspondence, ecology, history and archaeology, photographs and images, and protection and management records. Please note: dates reflect the subject content of the material.

item.geogname: Bill Williams River National Wildlife Refuge (Ariz.)

did.unittitle: Subgroup 1: The Nature Conservancy in Arizona, Chapter Materials, 1962-1999

scopecontent.p: The materials in Subgroup 1 consist of the administration (1970-1997), correspondence (1964-1999), communications (1968-1997), program (1975-1998), and research and reference (1962-1996) records of the organization. Administration files contain four subseries: Board of Trustees (1992-1994), Development (1970-1997), Operations (1990-1994), and Organizational History (1974-1994). Correspondence files contain two subseries: Chronological (1991-1994) and General (1964-1999). Communications files contain three subseries: Media-Public Relations (1990-1996), Newsletters (1968-1994) and Publications (1990-1997). Program files contain two subseries: Arizona Natural Heritage Program (1975-1988) and Volunteer Program (1989-1998). Research and Reference files contain six subseries: Federal Agencies (1975-1992), Maps and Aerial Images (1971-1992), News Clippings (1966-1979), Organizations and Institutions (1977-1996), Plans and Reports (1978-1994), and Subject (1962-1992).

This series contains four subseries: Board of Trustees (1992-1993), Development (1970-1997), Operations (1990-1994), and Organizational History (1974-1994). Board of Trustees files include the meeting minutes and a list of officers, trustees and advisory council members. Development files document the financial planning, fundraising and strategic planning activities of the organization. Operations files include the fiscal management, budgets and planning documents. Organizational History files include the chapter bylaws, general information, manuals and directories from the national organization, and original office space documentation.

scopecontent.p: This series contains two subseries: Chronological (1991-1994) and General (1964-1999). Chronological files include the monthly internal memoranda and external correspondence of the administration and staff of the organization. General correspondence includes both internal and external correspondence by name, subject, legislation, legislators or organizations.

This series contains three subseries: Media-Public Relations (1990-1996), Newsletters (1968-1994) and Publications (1990-1997). The Media-Public Relations files document legislative, general and press-related public relations activities. Newsletters includes regularly issued newsletters of The Nature Conservancy, Arizona Chapter and the national organization. Publications include magazines and other published materials produced by the national organization.

unittitle.title: "Designing a Geography of Hope, Guidelines for Ecoregion-Based Conservation in the Nature Conservancy."

scopecontent.p: This series contains two subseries: Arizona Natural Heritage Program (1975-1988) and Volunteer Program (1989-1998). The Arizona Natural Heritage Program files document the activities of this collaborative program between The Nature Conservancy, Arizona Chapter and The Arizona Game and Fish Department. Material includes: fiscal administration, operations, reports, correspondence, ecological resources, history, media and publicity, and protection and management of various ecological resources and sites. The Volunteer Program files document staff and volunteer activities including: coordination, correspondence, management, general information, recruitment, reports, recognition, and stewardship projects at various sites.

scopecontent.p: This series contains six subseries: Federal Agencies (1975-1992), Maps and Aerial Images (1971-1992), News Clippings (1966-1979), Organizations and Institutions (1977-1996), Plans and Reports (1978-1994), and Subject files (1962-1992). Federal Agencies documents the materials produced by various federal agencies. Maps and Aerial Images includes maps and aerial images of sites and geographic areas of interest and the documentation and procedures for identifying and requesting these images. News Clippings documents various events and subjects of interest. Organizations and Institutions includes information produced by non-profit environmental and other organizations. Plans and Reports includes plans and reports generated by various state and federal government agencies, institutions, and The Nature Conservancy, national organization on various methods, ecological resources and areas of interest. Subject files include material arranged by topic.

scopecontent.p: The material in Subgroup 2 consists of the site files of the organization, which contain forty-two series arranged alphabetically by site name. Each series in this subgroup may include one or all of the following subseries: Administration, Correspondence, Ecology, History and Archaeology, Photographs and Images, and Protection and Management. The forty-two site file series include: Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch Sanctuary (1972-1996), Aravaipa Canyon Preserve (1949-1993), Arivaca Creek (1978-1989), Baboquivari Mountains Macrosite (1969-1984), Bill Williams River Megasite (1975-1994), Buenos Aires National Wildlife Refuge (1982-1992), Canelo Hills Cienega Preserve (1967-1993), Chiricahua Cave Creek Macrosite (1987), Chiricahua Portal Preserve (1988), Chiricahua Turkey Creek (1982), Coffeepot Mountain Macrosite (1977-1986), Eagle Creek Natural Area (1977-1986), Empire Ranch Megasite (1986), Escondido Falls (1986), Goodding RNA Extensions (1987), Guadalupe Canyon (1979-1982), Hartwell Canyon Preserve (1986-1989), Hassayampa River Preserve (1986-1994), Holbrook NE Site (1981), Jak Ranch (1988), Kino Springs (1978-1989), Kiper Springs (1979-1989), Leslie Spring (1986-1988), McDowell Mountains (1995), Muleshoe Ranch Cooperative Management Area (1884-1997), Oracle State Park (1973-1989), Patagonia-Sonoita Creek Preserve (1965-1993), Ramsey Canyon Preserve (1953-1993), Rio Yaqui Headwaters System (1983), Sabino Creek Macrosite (undated), San Bernardino Ranch Site (1979-1983), San Francisco Peaks Site (1988), San Pedro River Biopreserve (1973-1998), San Rafael Valley Macrosite (1980), Santa Rita Experimental Range ( 1987), Tavasci Marsh Site (1973-1993), Tumamoc Hill Site (1987-1990), Vekol Valley Special Management Area (1988), Volunteer Canyon-Smith Road Site (1988-1990), Waterman Mountains Site (1986-1988), White Canyon (1989), and Whitewater Draw (1991).
This series contains one subseries: Protection and Management (1972-1996). Files include general information, a management plan and an annotated bibliography relevant to this site.

This series contains six subseries: Administration (1970-1993), Correspondence (1970-1975), Ecology (1950-1989), History and Archaeology (1953-1973), Photographs and Images (undated), and Protection and Management (1949-1990). Files document land purchases, general correspondence, ecological resources, prehistoric and historic land use, management, recreational use and stewardship of the preserve.
